title: Ukraine war live: Putin calls for ‘direct talks’ with Kyiv but says west must stop arming Ukraine
snippets:
In late-night address in Moscow, Russian president dismissed calls by European leaders for 30-day ceasefire to start on Monday

Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, has just welcomed Vladimir Putin’s proposal for direct talks in Istanbul on Thursday, but said his team is expecting Moscow to agree to a “lasting” ceasefire starting tomorrow.

In a post on X, Zelenskyy, without responding explicitly to Putin’s invitation for talks in Turkey, wrote:

It is a positive sign that the Russians have finally begun to consider ending the war.

The entire world has been waiting for this for a very long time. And the very first step in truly ending any war is a ceasefire. There is no point in continuing the killing even for a single day.

Continue reading...
titles: Ukraine war live: Putin calls for ‘direct talks’ with Kyiv but says west must stop arming Ukraine
summary: In a late-night address, Russian President Vladimir Putin dismissed European calls for a 30-day ceasefire. Meanwhile, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy welcomed Putin's proposal for direct talks in Istanbul, emphasizing the need for a "lasting" ceasefire starting immediately. Zelenskyy expressed optimism about Russia considering ending the war, highlighting that a ceasefire is the first step toward peace. The talks between the leaders are a significant development in the ongoing conflict.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a useful update on the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the situation. It reports on a potential solution (direct talks), but does not offer any concrete progress or actionable insights.

title: Newcastle v Chelsea and El Clásico headline crucial set of games – matchday live
snippets:
• Follow all the latest news and buildup to Sunday’s games
  • Live scores | Tables | And mail matchday live or post BTL

Arne Slot is planning to turn Trent Alexander-Arnold’s Anfield departure into a positive for Liverpool, the head coach has said. The right-back will leave Merseyside this summer for Real Madrid on a free transfer, meaning the Dutchman will need to find a way of replacing him.

Conor Bradley is set to start Sunday’s Premier League meeting with Arsenal at Anfield as preparations continue for next season with the title secured. Slot might have to look outside the club for someone to challenge the Northern Ireland international for the right-back berth.

Any regrets from the Rangers years? Denny

Oh Christ, aye. I never gave myself the best chance to break through at Rangers. I wasn’t training. An amateur player would have been training harder than me. I just wasn’t dedicated enough. I thought I’d made it. Football was easy to me. I’d never had an injury, I came through at Dundee United and I was ripping it up. But then you start to get injured. You’re going on nights out, you’re not playing and it all starts to mount up. There’s a wee bit of trouble creeping into my life now. I’ve got massive regrets that I never gave myself the best crack at it because I was a Rangers boy, I supported Rangers when I was younger, but there is always a silver lining. If I’d cracked it at Rangers I wouldn’t have come to Everton.

Continue reading...
titles: Newcastle v Chelsea and El Clásico headline crucial set of games – matchday live
summary: Trent Alexander-Arnold is set to leave Liverpool for Real Madrid on a free transfer this summer, as confirmed by head coach Arne Slot. Slot views Alexander-Arnold's departure as an opportunity to positively reshape the team. Conor Bradley is expected to replace Alexander-Arnold in the upcoming Premier League game against Arsenal, indicating preparations for next season are underway with Liverpool having secured the title. Additionally, a personal reflection from a former player highlights the challenges and regrets faced during his career, emphasizing the importance of dedication in profession
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the upcoming football matches and the potential impact of player transfers. It offers some insight into team strategies and the potential for progress (reshaping the team). However, it does not provide a deep understanding of the system or trends in football.

title: Out of Europe, out of ideas? Manchester City women face big summer rebuild | Tom Garry
snippets:
City must respond to Chelsea’s dominance and the identity of their next manager will be key

Even as the party anthems blasted out under sunny Manchester skies and the home fans showed their appreciation after a seven-goal thriller, the celebratory mood could not fully mask the undertone of disappointment at the Joie Stadium, for a club wondering what might have been.

On the season’s final day 12 months ago, Manchester City missed out on the title only on goal difference. This time, they finished 17 points off the runaway champions Chelsea. Worse still, City dropped outside the European places.

Continue reading...
titles: Out of Europe, out of ideas? Manchester City women face big summer rebuild | Tom Garry
summary: Manchester City finished the season 17 points behind champions Chelsea, a significant drop from the previous year when they narrowly missed the title on goal difference. The team also fell out of the European places, marking a disappointing end to their campaign. Amidst celebrations at the Joie Stadium, there was a sense of what could have been for City. The appointment of their next manager is seen as crucial for the club to challenge Chelsea's dominance and improve their standing.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about Manchester City's performance and the challenges they face in the upcoming season. It offers insights into the team's current situation and the importance of their next managerial appointment. However, it does not report on any solutions or improvements, and its awareness level is limited to the context of football.

title: How Dopamine Flips the Brain’s Fear Switch – And Turns On Calm
snippets: Researchers at MIT have uncovered a powerful way the brain “unlearns” fear: through a dopamine-driven reward signal. By tracing a pathway between dopamine-producing neurons and two types of cells in the amygdala, scientists discovered that dopamine not only signals danger but also plays a crucial role in calming fears by encouraging positive learning. This insight [...]
titles: How Dopamine Flips the Brain’s Fear Switch – And Turns On Calm
summary: Researchers at MIT have discovered that dopamine plays a crucial role in helping the brain overcome fear by promoting positive learning experiences. This is achieved through a connection between dopamine-producing neurons and two types of cells in the amygdala. The study reveals that dopamine signals both danger and safety, facilitating the process of "unlearning" fear.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides a deeper understanding of how the brain functions, particularly in relation to fear and calmness. It reports on a significant scientific discovery and explains its implications, thereby increasing the reader's awareness of the brain's complex systems. The story also has potential usefulness for those interested in neuroscience or mental health.

title: Life’s Greatest Leap: Scientists Decode the Origins of Complex Cells
snippets: Eukaryogenesis occurred suddenly, driven by the growing length of genes and the limitations on producing longer proteins. An international team of four senior scientists from Mainz, Valencia, Madrid, and Zurich has published groundbreaking research in the journal PNAS that explores one of the most significant leaps in the evolution of life on Earth: the origin [...]
titles: Life’s Greatest Leap: Scientists Decode the Origins of Complex Cells
summary: Scientists have made a significant discovery regarding the origin of complex cells, a pivotal moment in the evolution of life on Earth known as eukaryogenesis. The research, conducted by an international team from Mainz, Valencia, Madrid, and Zurich, and published in the journal PNAS, suggests that the sudden leap towards complex cellular life was driven by the increasing length of genes and the inherent limitations in producing longer proteins. This groundbreaking study provides crucial insights into how complex cells evolved.
constructiveness_reason: This story is extremely constructive. It reports on a major scientific breakthrough, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the evolution of life on Earth. The story highlights the progress made in the field of cellular biology and the implications of this discovery. It increases the reader's awareness of biological systems and the origins of complex cellular life.

These materials have recently garnered international attention. A research team led by Prof. [...]
titles: Physicists Discover First Room-Temperature 2D Altermagnet
summary: Physicists have discovered the first room-temperature 2D altermagnet, a new class of layered antiferromagnets that allows for efficient spin control without the need for spin–orbit coupling or net magnetization. This groundbreaking finding, led by a research team including Prof. [...], highlights altermagnets' potential for momentum-dependent spin splitting, marking a significant advancement in the field and attracting global interest in these materials.

title: Scientists Create Ultra-Rare Hydrogen-6 Isotope, Defying Nuclear Physics
snippets: For the first time, the extremely neutron-rich hydrogen isotope ⁶H has been produced and measured using an electron scattering experiment, revealing unexpectedly strong interactions between neutrons within the nucleus. Researchers from the A1 Collaboration at the Institute of Nuclear Physics, Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz (JGU), in partnership with scientists from China and Japan, have successfully [...]
titles: Scientists Create Ultra-Rare Hydrogen-6 Isotope, Defying Nuclear Physics
summary: Scientists from the A1 Collaboration at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz, alongside Chinese and Japanese researchers, have successfully created and measured the ultra-rare hydrogen isotope Hydrogen-6 (⁶H) for the first time. This achievement was made using an electron scattering experiment, which revealed strong interactions between neutrons in the nucleus, challenging existing nuclear physics theories.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides a deeper understanding of a new scientific achievement, challenging existing nuclear physics theories. It informs about an innovation in the field of nuclear physics and contributes to the reader's knowledge about scientific progress.

title: Einstein’s Relativity Predicted a Twisted Illusion – Now Scientists Have Finally Seen It
snippets: Physicists in Vienna have recreated a bizarre visual illusion from Einstein’s relativity—the Terrell-Penrose effect—by simulating slow light speeds with lasers and cameras. A fast-moving cube appears twisted, as predicted over 60 years ago. Relativity Gets Weird at Light-Speed When things move really, really fast, close to the speed of light, our everyday ideas about space [...]
titles: Einstein’s Relativity Predicted a Twisted Illusion – Now Scientists Have Finally Seen It
summary: Physicists in Vienna have successfully observed the Terrell-Penrose effect, a phenomenon predicted by Einstein's theory of relativity. Using lasers and cameras to simulate the effect of slow light speeds, they demonstrated that a fast-moving cube appears twisted, confirming predictions made over 60 years ago. This experiment highlights the strange behaviors of objects moving at speeds close to the speed of light, challenging conventional perceptions of space.
constructiveness_reason: The story is highly constructive as it reports on a significant scientific breakthrough which confirms a prediction made by Einstein's theory of relativity. This provides the reader with a deeper understanding of the subject and increases awareness about the strange behaviors of objects moving at high speeds.
